Dear Dr. Kolodchin:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Former Youth A told Complainant she had sexual contact with an
unidentified male youth at the facility between 4/10/24 - 4/23/24
implying inadequate staff supervision.
Investigation I was assigned this investigation on 5/1/24.
Safehaus Too is a four-bed non-secure short-term co-ed facility
that does not contract with MDHHS and does not have video
cameras inside the residential home.
Interviews:
I interviewed Complainant on 5/1/24. On 4/29/24 Complainant
said Youth A told her she and a boy were laying together under
blankets in the general living area and had sexual relations when
the staff left the room. “Youth A said she wanted to do it and
wouldn’t tell me the boy’s name. I encouraged her to go to a teen
health center, but I did not tell her foster mother.”
On 5/1/24 I notified Chief Administrator that an investigation was
in progress pertaining to the supervision of Youth A when she was
at the facility, and I would share more information once I had it.
2

On 5/2/24 I notified Youth A’s PAFC Worker that I was assigned
to investigate possible inadequate supervision at Safehaus Too
based on Youth A’s disclosure. I asked PAFC Worker to inform
Youth A’s foster mother about what allegedly took place at
Safehaus Too.
On 5/3/24 PAFC Worker emailed indicating she informed the
foster mother. I attempted to arrange to interview Youth A at the
private foster care agency. However, transportation for her could
not be arranged. PAFC Worker indicated Youth A would be
attending Adams Middle School in Westland on 5/7/24.
I interviewed Former Youth A at school on 5/7/24. Prior to the
interview, I clarified that Youth A was not in any trouble and I was
only there to find out about how she was supervised at Safehaus.
Youth A confirmed that she resided at Safehaus from 4/10/24 –
4/23/24 but said she could not recall any of the names of the staff.
I asked her if there were any boys at the facility. She said there
was one but she did not know his name. I asked Youth A if she
and a boy had sexual contact at Safehaus. Her eyes widened and
she demanded, “Who said that?” I reiterated I was there to make
sure the staff are supervising the youth at Safehaus. She said the
staff there do supervise the youths and “never leave us alone.”
Youth A became angry and focused on who may have told. She
insisted, “I’m not telling you nothing. That’s a lie. I’m not telling
you cuz I didn’t do it with no boy…It didn’t happen. No. You’re
going to go to his school and ask him. I’m not doing this. Who
told you that? Oh, it was probably that youth worker. What a
fuckin’ snitch, man.” She became tearful and stormed out of the
room.
I attempted to interview Former Youth R with Government
Worker by phone on 5/14/24 at his mothers phone number. His
mother said Former Youth R was not staying with her and was
unwilling or unable to provide a number where her son could be
reached.
Government Worker and I reached Former Youth R on 5/15/24.
He said he knew Former Youth A and they talked together.
Former Youth R denied sharing or trying to share a blanket with
Former Youth A. “There was one full fluffy blanket that we would
all fight over. One staff told us not to sit close, but we were
already arms-length away.”
3

I arrived unannounced at Safehaus Too on 5/8/24 and met with
Chief Administrator (CA). I shared the allegations and gathered
additional information. CA indicated that Youth A and one male
youth, Former Youth R, age 14, were at the facility together from
4/10/24 – 4/16/24.
I interviewed Former Staff 1 on 5/9/24 by phone. She worked at
the facility for two months and worked afternoon shift on 4/10/24
and 4/11/24. Former Staff 1 said she was terminated on 4/13/24
because she reported to work smelling of alcohol.
Former Staff 1 remembered Youth A and Youth R. She said she
could see they liked each other because there was lots of giggling.
“I saw they were sitting too close in chairs and would say,
‘Boundaries.’ I told my coworkers to keep an eye on them.
Former Staff 1 denied seeing the youths touch each other or
sharing a blanket. She denied ever leaving them alone together
or being aware of or hearing rumors that they had sexual contact.
I interviewed Staff 2 on 5/9/24 by phone. She has worked at the
facility for three months. Staff 2 worked afternoon shift at
Safehaus Too on 4/11/24. She denied witnessing any
inappropriate behaviors between Youth A and Youth R. “I saw
them talking. They were never underneath a blanket. I wouldn’t
allow that.”
I interviewed Staff 3 on 5/9/24 by phone. He has worked at the
facility for three months. Staff 3 worked afternoon shift at
Safehaus Too on 4/12/24 and 4/16/24. He remembered Youth A
and Youth R. “They appeared to be regular middle school friends.
There was no sharing of chairs or blankets.”
I interviewed Staff 4 on 5/9/24 by phone. She has worked at the
facility for two weeks. Staff 4 worked afternoon shift on 4/14/24
and remembered both youths. “I could not say they were close. I
did not see blanket sharing during my shift. I saw nothing
inappropriate between them.”
Staff 5 worked afternoon shift at the facility on 4/13/24 and
4/16/24. I attempted to reach Staff 5 twice on 5/9/24 to interview
him. He did not answer or return my calls.
I interviewed Staff 6 on 5/9/24 by phone. She has worked at the
facility for 11 days and worked afternoon shift on 4/15/24. During
shift change, Staff 6 recalled being warned to keep a close eye on
Youth A and Youth R as there were rumors from other unidentified
youths that they had had sexual contact. Staff 6 remembered
4

both youths and described them as “a little cozy.” “I kept having to
separate them and remind them of boundaries. I did not witness
any touching, but I believe they would have had I not been
supervising.” Staff 6 said Youth A and Youth R were sitting in
chairs watching television and threw a blanket over themselves. “I
separated them, they questioned why and said they weren’t doing
anything…I told them to get up for an activity and they gave me a
hard time. They tried sharing a blanket a couple more times, then
agreed not to sit next to each other. I had Youth A sit by me.
Former Staff 1 turned off the lights for “movie time” at 9pm. It was
rumored Youth A and Youth R liked each other.” Later Staff 6
heard unidentified youths saying that Former Staff 1 was aware
there had been sexual contact between the two youths. Staff 6
was adamant “They didn’t touch each other while I was there.”
I interviewed Staff 7 on 5/9/24 by phone. She has worked at the
facility for five months and worked afternoon shift on 4/16/24.
Staff 7 remembered both youths and said Youth A was “always
the center of attention.” “I could see Youth A liked Youth R…The
girls act differently when there’s a boy in the house…I never saw a
blanket over them...They were not left in a room together without
staff when I was there…I didn’t hear any rumors about them.”
I attempted to interview Staff 8 with Government Worker by phone
on 5/14/24 via phone. A voice message was left. I interviewed
Staff 8 with Government Worker on 5/15/24. She works midnight
shift, remembered Youth A, never saw her close to Youth R and
said, “No one was under blankets.”
Analysis Youth A stated that staff were always in the room with them when
the youths were awake. All afternoon staff interviewed denied
leaving Youth A and Youth R alone together in a room.
There is no evidence Youth A and Youth R were left unsupervised
on afternoon shift.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Staff to resident ratio
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127
Section (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
Description supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
5

checks of residents. The time between the variable interval checks
shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff slept at night allowing Youth A to have sexual contact with
unidentified youths.
Investigation On 5/10/24 I received this additional allegation assigned as a joint
investigation with Government Worker.
I notified Chief Administrator about the additional allegation.
Safehaus Too is a four-bed non-secure short-term co-ed facility
that does not contract with MDHHS and does not have video
cameras inside the residential home.
Documents reviewed:
I reviewed bed check logs dated 4/10/24 through 4/23/24. On
4/10/24 and 4/12/24, two bed checks on Former Youth A were 23
minutes and 17 minutes apart, respectively, exceeding fifteen
minutes. On 4/10/24, four bed checks on Former Youth R were
19 minutes, 22 minutes, 24 minutes and 23 minutes apart,
exceeding fifteen minutes.
Analysis The times between variable interval eye-on checks exceeded
fifteen minutes.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule of Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Unidentified staff was asleep during midnight shift between
4/10/24 and 4/23/24.
6

Investigation On 5/10/24 I received this additional allegation assigned as a joint
investigation with Government Worker.
Safehaus Too is a four-bed non-secure short-term co-ed facility
that does not contract with MDHHS and does not have video
cameras inside the residential home.
Interviews:
I interviewed Wayne County Integrated Health staff by phone on
5/10/24. She was in a Teams meeting on 5/8/24 when an
unidentified worker announced that Youth A told her an
unidentified staff at Safehaus Too slept while on duty.
I notified Chief Administrator at Safehaus Too about the additional
allegation received on 5/10/24.
On 5/9/24 Former Youth A was interviewed again by
Government Worker, and she denied knowledge of a staff person
sleeping.
Former Youth R said one unidentified night, he woke up to use
the bathroom and saw an unidentified female staff lying asleep on
the couch. He said no other staff were there but he was not
bothered by it and just went back to his room.
Government Worker and I attempted to reach Former Staff 1
again on 5/14/24 and 5/15/24 but her phone was out of service.
I interviewed Staff 2 again with Government Worker on 5/14/24 by
phone. She said she did not witness or have knowledge of any
staff sleeping on duty.
I contacted Staff 3 again with Government Worker by phone on
5/14/24. He refused to talk to us until he obtained supervisory
permission and said he would call back. Government Worker and
I interviewed Staff 3 a third time on 5/15/24. He denied ever
seeing a coworker asleep during his shift. Staff 3 did however
smell alcohol on Former Staff 1 as he was leaving, and she was
arriving. Staff 3 said he notified the Director and drove Former
Staff 1 home. “Former Staff 1 did not work after that.”
Staff 5 worked afternoon shift at the facility on 4/13/24 and
4/16/24. I attempted to reach Staff 5 twice on 5/9/24 to interview
him. He did not answer or return my calls. I interviewed Staff 5
with Government Worker on 5/15/24. He remembered Youth A
and Youth R but did not observe any inappropriate interactions
7

between them. Staff 5 also denied witnessing staff asleep while
on duty.
I interviewed Staff 6 again with Government Worker on 5/24/24 by
phone. She denied witnessing staff sleeping on duty. However,
Staff 6 said “It was rumored Former Staff 1 fell asleep a couple
times. Youth A told me she found Former Staff 1 “knocked out.”
I interviewed Staff 7 again with Government Worker on 5/14/24 by
phone. She denied witnessing or having knowledge of any staff
sleeping on duty.
Staff 8 denied seeing any staff person sleeping at work.
On 5/14/24 Staff 9 and Staff 11’s phones were out of service.
I interviewed Staff 9 with Government Worker by phone on
5/15/24. She remembered Youth A and denied seeing her
interact inappropriately with other youths. Staff 9 usually works
alone on the midnight shift. When Former Staff 1 was new and
shadowing Staff 9, Staff 9 said Former Staff 1 “sort of dozed off,”
likely because she was not accustomed to working midnight shift.
“Former Staff 1 only worked there a month.”
I interviewed Staff 11 with Government Worker on 5/15/24 by
phone. She works midnight shift. On their first days working
midnight shift, she witnessed Staff 2 and Former Staff 1 fall asleep
but said the children never went unsupervised. “I sit in the hallway
and monitor all night, then record it on logs.” Staff 11 denied ever
smelling alcohol on any staff member.
Document Reviewed:
I reviewed the agency’s policy regarding Rules of Conduct for
Staff which indicates sleeping while on duty is cause for
immediate termination.
Government Worker’s findings were undetermined.
Analysis On two separate occasions, Staff 9 and Staff 11 said they noticed
Former Staff 1 and Staff 2 doze off during midnight shift. On a
third occasion, in the middle of the night, Youth R saw an
unidentified staff asleep on the couch. The agency’s policy
indicates sleeping on duty is cause for termination. Former Staff 1
was terminated before this allegation was received for reporting to
work smelling of alcohol.
8

Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
